awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Equipment to Develop an Ubiquitous Wireless Sensor Network for Measurement, Modeling, and Prediction in Water Resource Management

por.por_cntn:
To advance the understanding of hydrodynamics of waterbodies and to develop tools for sustainable water management, this project aims at achieving a potentially transformative change in water resource sustainable management through application of state-of-the-art Wireless Sensor Network (WSN) technology and revolutionizing water quantity and quality modeling and predictions through intensive data acquisition while minimizing resource usage. Customized WSNs based on eKo Pro Environmental Monitoring Systems from Memsic Corp., WSNs product from National Instruments, and STORM 3 Data Loggers from YSI have been tested and deployed to monitor the pond at the John Gray Center at Lamar University and Neches River Salt Water Barrier, Beaumont, TX. Reliable and energy efficient data collection protocols for WSNs are studied in a lab setting. Various sensor probes (temperature, Dissolved Oxygen, water pH, Turbidity, Conductivity) have been tested for relevant products. Significant efforts are still required to maintain the deployed WSN system to make them function properly.

After Lab testing, real-time and in-situ water quality data at fine temporal granularities have been collected, calibrated, and validated. The prototype WSN can connect to an ArcGIS (Geographic Information System) based system to archive and present collected data over a large range of time scales and geographical area. An ArcGIS based application has been developed to effectively manage the collected data. A web-based map application also makes it possible for collected sensor readings to be vividly accessible for a wide variety of remote researchers.

These data are further utilized to enable water quality and quantity model. A one-dimensional, unsteady water quality model has been applied to simulate the T and DO variation over 3 years from 2014 to 2016 in a retention pond at Lamar University, and a two-dimensional computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model has also been developed using finite volume numerical solver to simulate flow fields and water temperatures for typical weather conditions in late spring and early fall. The results indicate that the thermal pollution and anaerobic conditions are evaluated as the main causes of the eutrophication using data collected by WSNs and model predictions. A surface aerator has been installed to improve the water circulation, which in turn to increase DO to be more than 4 ppm and diminish the harmful algal. The study demonstrates an improved decision-making as a result of the combination of WSNs and water quality models and provides a better practice tool for water resource management in a retention pond. The ongoing research effort is to develop a HEC-RAS model using WSNs data to predict the non-point source from runoff and the morphology change in front of the Salt Barrier after hurricane Harvey.

Our tested and constructed WSN system has provided an excellent environment for students to study hands-on projects about wireless networking, embedded operating systems, database, and?. Results have been integrated into various courses lectured by the PIs. Our constructed system will provide students with an excellent infrastructure to carry out research in wireless networking and water models

In addition, the instrument and facility under this project have helped the PIs with other related funding to deal with the coastal water quality and water infrastructures, e.g. Waterway, drainage system, wetland, etc.
